item.title: ICE Says It Has No Videos to Release of Chicago Deportation Operations
item.description: The response to an information request contradicted the administration’s public testimony and raised concerns that it may be trying to evade oversight.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal agent in tactical gear confronted residents in the Little Village neighborhood of Chicago in October.

item.title: Judge in Oregon Blocks Arrest of Protesters For Noise
item.description: Federal agents outside an ICE detention facility in Eugene, Ore., had sought to enforce a new rule that prohibits “creating a loud or unusual noise” outside federal property.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: In October, federal agents arrested a person outside of a federal ICE detention center in Portland.

item.title: Defense Bill Will Make D.C. Skies Less Safe, N.T.S.B. Chair Says
item.description: The chair of the National Transportation Safety Board warned that a provision in the new defense bill would worsen the risk of midair collisions near the Washington-area airport where a deadly crash in January killed 67 people.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Jennifer Homendy, the N.T.S.B. chair, said she would be concerned about the safety of flying in Washington’s airspace if the provision became law.

item.title: Oil Tanker U.S. Seized Off Venezuela Has Faked Its Location Before, Data Shows
item.description: The ship has frequently carried oil from countries under U.S. sanctions, and its tracking data shows multiple recent trips to Iran and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Riley Mellen

item.title: Always on My Mind: Trump’s Enduring Focus on Joe Biden
item.description: After nearly 11 months in office, the president’s tendency to talk about his predecessor is more pronounced than ever.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump and President Biden at Mr. Trump’s inauguration in January. Mr. Trump’s allies dispute the idea that he is obsessed with his predecessor.

item.title: House Gives Bipartisan Approval to $900 Billion Defense Bill
item.description: The legislation codifies President Trump’s agenda but includes a few measures challenging his policies and insisting on more consultation with Congress.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson at the Capitol on Wednesday.

item.title: What Democrats Can Learn From Biden’s Immigration Policy Mistakes
item.description: As 2028 takes shape, Democrats will face a version of the same dilemma.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the U.S.-Mexico border in El Paso in 2023.

item.title: What Is a Trump Gold Card? Applications Open for Million-Dollar Visas.
item.description: President Trump has framed the program as a way for the government to raise billions of dollars and prioritize the admission of successful entrepreneurs and investors.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo

item.title: After Shutdown, Democrats Claim Credit for Funding They Opposed
item.description: Several Democrats who fought to steer federal money to their states and districts have boasted about their success even after voting against the bill that provided the funds.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson

item.title: $2 Billion in Pentagon Funds Said to Go to Anti-Immigrant Operations
item.description: Democratic lawmakers said in a report that shifting Defense Department funding to support the Trump administration’s immigration agenda has hurt military readiness.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Army soldier overlooking the border between the United States and Mexico near Santa Teresa, N.M., in April.

item.title: Judge Emil Bove Faces Ethics Complaint for Attending Trump Rally
item.description: One of the president’s appeals-court nominees, a former lawyer for the president, was in the crowd at a raucous event in Mt. Pocono, Pa.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Emil Bove III attended a rally for President Trump on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Seized Oil Tanker Off Venezuelan Coast
item.description: The seizure comes as the United States builds up its forces in the Caribbean as part of a campaign against President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.media:description: President Trump announced the seizure at the White House on Wednesday, without giving details on the operation.

item.title: How the Tate Brothers Returned to the United States
item.description: Andrew Tate and his brother, Tristan, were prohibited from leaving Romania for years after they were accused of trafficking dozens of women for a porn business. Our investigative reporter Megan Twohey reveals how the Tates courted powerful figures on the American right in order to gain their freedom to travel to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Megan Twohey, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, David Seekamp, Jon Miller, Joey Sendaydiego and James Surdam

item.title: Army Gynecologist Charged With Secretly Recording Over 40 Patients
item.description: Members of Congress expressed concerns that the Army dismissed complaints about the doctor, who was accused of secretly recording patients at Fort Hood in Texas.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S. Army Office of Special Trial Counsel said the charges covered crimes that the doctor committed against 44 victims this year.

item.title: How Andrew Tate, Manosphere Star Accused of Rape and Trafficking, Was Freed
item.description: Barred from leaving Romania, Andrew Tate courted powerful figures on the American right, from Tucker Carlson to Barron Trump. Then an extraordinary order let him go.
item.dc:creator: Megan Twohey and Isabella Kwai

item.title: ‘Rocky’ Statue to Move to Where It Started: Philadelphia’s Art Museum Steps
item.description: It’s a symbol of the city. But is it art?
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Sylvester Stallone with the Rocky statue outside the Philadelphia Art Museum in 2018.

item.title: A Stranger Found Ricki Lake’s Lost Family Photos After L.A. Wildfires
item.description: Patty Scanlon bought a box of snapshots for $20 at a flea market and was stunned to find family photos of Ms. Lake, whose house burned down in January.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Wenne Alton Davis, Actor in ‘Marvelous Mrs. Maisel,’ Hit by S.U.V. and Killed
item.description: The actor, 60, was struck by a vehicle in Midtown Manhattan late on Monday, her agent and the police said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Agriculture Department Approves More Soda Bans for Food Stamps
item.description: Six more states have been approved for waivers that ban the purchase of some sugary foods and beverages using food stamps.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:description: The restrictions were characterized as an example of the Make America Healthy Again agenda.

item.title: What Could Thwart the Texas G.O.P. From Picking Up 5 House Seats in Midterm Elections
item.description: Republicans redid their voting map so they could flip five seats to help keep control of the U.S. House. But achieving that goal is far from guaranteed.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Seguin in Texas’ 35th Congressional District, part of the new voting map that state lawmakers adopted. The district is expected to be closely contested in next year’s midterms.

item.title: Ethics Agency Says Bryan Bedford, FAA Chief, Didn’t Divest Republic Airways Holdings
item.description: The Office of Government Ethics told senators that Bryan Bedford, the F.A.A. administrator, did not divest from the airline he previously ran as he had agreed.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bryan Bedford was the chairman and chief executive of Republic Airways before being confirmed as the administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration earlier this year.

item.title: Denied Federal Disaster Aid, a Town in Trump Country Feels Forgotten
item.description: FEMA rejected requests for federal assistance, twice, after devastating floods in western Maryland, part of a larger pattern of making communities pay for their own disaster recovery.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Wesley Lapointe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spring flooding in Allegany County, Md., caused an estimated $33.7 million in damage.

item.title: Judge Says Trump Must End Guard Deployment in Los Angeles
item.description: A federal judge ruled that the Trump administration had illegally kept troops in Los Angeles after emergency conditions had ended. The administration is expected to appeal.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: California National Guard troops guarding a federal building in Los Angeles in June.

item.title: House Democrat Seeks to Impeach RFK Jr. for Undercutting Public Health
item.description: The move by Representative Haley Stevens, a Michigan Democrat who is running for Senate, does not have the support of her party’s leaders and is all but certain to fail.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. at the White House.

item.title: Democrats Press to Expand House Map, Targeting 5 New G.O.P. Seats
item.description: Four of the additions are for districts where President Trump won handily, but Democrats are feeling emboldened by election outcomes this fall.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: The seat of Representative Darrell Issa, a Republican whose California district Democrats redrew to lean Democratic, is among those added to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee’s list of “districts in play.”

item.title: Supreme Court Grapples With Death Penalty Case on Intellectual Disability
item.description: The case involves an Alabama man who challenged his death sentence after a murder conviction because of his varying results in a series of I.Q. tests.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two decades ago, the Supreme Court barred the execution of people with mental disabilities as a violation of the Constitution’s Eighth Amendment ban on cruel and unusual punishment. But the court’s composition has changed.

item.title: Democrats Make a Fresh Push to Win State Legislatures
item.description: The arm of the party that focuses on statehouses is targeting hundreds of seats and more than 40 chambers, according to a strategy memo, reflecting Democrats’ new optimism.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: The Arizona State Capitol in Phoenix. The state is one of several with Republican-controlled legislatures that Democrats are trying to flip.

item.title: A Cinnabon Worker Was Fired for a Racist Slur. Her Supporters Have Raised $130,000.
item.description: On a video that went viral, the worker, who is white, can be seen calling two Black customers an epithet. The campaign to give her money echoes the reaction to a similar incident this year.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times

item.title: Republicans Are Fighting With One Another in Deep-Red Indiana. Here’s Why.
item.description: Some Republicans in the Indiana Senate have resisted a new congressional map despite lobbying from the White House and threats of political consequences.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The fight over redistricting has intensified in the Indiana legislature in recent weeks.

item.title: The Conservative Overhaul of the University of Texas Is Underway
item.description: The school has been brought to heel by conservative critics of higher education. It is part of a broader transformation at the state’s universities.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel and Callaghan O’Hare
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Republican lawyer, not an academic, now runs the University of Texas at Austin. Other changes are also underway.
